column1: Which driver will win the 2022 Formula One World Drivers' Championship?
column5: ['Lewis Hamilton', 'Charles Leclerc', 'Sergio Perez', 'George Russell', 'Carlos Sainz', 'Max Verstappen', 'Another driver']
column6: ['Business', 'Technology', 'Sports', 'Entertainment']
#BravoZulu

Verstappen’s lead is so large (vs remaining points available from future races) that even if he, somehow, scored no further points for the rest of the season ( << 1% chance), it would still be exceedingly unlikely that any of the 5 drivers in mathematical contention would achieve the P1 / P2 positions with enough consistency to outscore him. For example, even Leclerc would need to win at least half of remaining races and place very highly in the rest, while Sainz would have to literally win every single race from here on out. This championship is all but mathematically over.

With 5 events left, Leclerc is 116 points back. At this point the only way to catch Verstappen would be if Verstappen had to drop from the season (crash, injury, illness, etc.) and Leclerc won every remaining event. Probably <1% but I'll round up until the next event on Oct 9.
Verstappen now has a commanding lead. The only thing that could prevent him winning at this stage is a bad crash which would put him out action for several races.

With recent race results, I no longer see a >1% chance of anyone but Verstappen taking the championship. It's possible that the total probability of someone *other than Verstappen* (but no specific driver) might be enough to put him back at 99%, I cannot give the other drivers less than a 1% chance in this question system. Therefore I'm giving it all to Verstappen.
Even if max failed to drive another race this season he would now take some catching so I upgrade to 100% prob

Verstappen now has a commanding lead. The only thing that could prevent him winning at this stage is a bad crash which would put him out action for several races. Hence leclerc and perez are still non zero but % has reduced

Verstappen has a dominant lead going into Monza, and with Ferrari and Mercedes having some strategic blunders in the last few races, it is unlikely that they will be able to make any bid for the drivers championship this season. Verstappen could have the title by Singapore if his success continues. Leclerc and Perez are his two closest competitors, but Leclerc's problems with Ferrari's poor strategies put him in an unlikely position for a comeback and Perez is almost completely out of the picture as it is clear RedBull favors Max and would likely prevent Perez from overtaking him in the standings.
https://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/max-verstappen-2022-f1-world-title-projection/10360167/

Given the latest races, it seems that Max has not only built himself a large lead but that the Red Bull car and team maintain a leg up over the others. Ferrari has signaled no plans to change or improve their current methods. Mercedes is looking better, but it's unclear that their improvements will continue far and quickly enough to overtake the Red Bull's performance in time for one of their drivers to take the title off Verstappen. I suspect it's more likely that Mercedes' improvements will leave them racing with Ferrari behind Red Bull, further hurting Ferrari's chances. While there exists a world where Red Bull thoroughly beefs it and has severe maintenance or strategy issues for the rest of the season, it is more likely that the team would fight and improve their way out of the situation than be left behind by the other teams for the rest of the season.

Verstappen has a significant lead, one of if not the bet car and is the preferred driver within the Red Bull garage. It would need a series of unfortunate events for Leclerc or anyone else to close the gap sufficiently. Not impossible but increasingly unlikely.
Odds are putting
Well, what did any of us expect would happen in Hungary? (Go Max!!!)
Ferrari strategy this season been comical. Probably not the difference as performance gap also too big, but they over complicate everything. A cultural problem as been going on so long now.
Updating post-France.

Max Verstappen has been coming up very strong the past seasons. With other teams struggling with their cars for now, no one else other than Charles Leclerc gets as close to Max. Charles has been struggling this year, he may be a good contender, but the car doesn't seem like its ready to take on Red Bull this season.Lewis Hamilton's comeback might possible have a chance there, but there's too much uncertainty to the Silver Arrows car even now.
Personally, not a fan of Max, but when Ecclestone says "Max has it easy" you know that now is not the time not to say...
Update after Austrian GP, Verstappen was lucky to get 2nd in the end.
Small update after British GP.

Reduced Hamilton and Russell to low single figures as likelihood of a dramatic improvement in Mercedes is decreasing while number of remaining races declining. Reduced Leclerc after underperformance in recent weeks. Pèrez remains low prob as is clear second choice driver for Red Bull making overall victory dependent on Verstappen DNFs or other acts of god. Sainz had his best race of the year in Montreal and still lost ground so still an outsider and also appears to be second choice vs Leclerc

Darn. Looks like this year’s championship “fight” will very probably not be as unpredictable and fun to watch as last year’s. VER seems to have an almost unassailable lead at this point. Remaining chances for VER not to win almost exclusively rely on scenarios where he can’t participate in a number of future races, e.g., because of a big accident. Would be as shocking as it is unlikely. New trends and dynamics could come into play at any time, as always, but after this many races, it seems like the chances of others catching up are shrinking fast with every additional race won by VER.
Russell seems very consistent. Verstappen is way ahead in points at this moment. So I increased his chance of winning.
Will come up properly, Leclerc on course for big engine penalties also.

Verstappen has a lead in the Championship. He's only failed to score high in races where he has had reliability issues early in the season, that is a risk but Ferrari have had issues recently so these things may even themselves out over the season and it seems like Red Bull have the better package. With Verstappen's current nearest rival being his teammate it's hard to see Red Bull not utilising team orders if it came to it to give Max the advantage.
Machines matter.

With a solidified lead in points for Verstappen and a repeating pattern of reliability issues for the drivers of Red Bull's closest competitors (Ferrari), his only real competition is the man in the same car and it's fairly clear to me that Red Bull is prioritizing Verstappen.
The two most recent races proves that Mercedes is not competitive enough to aim fot the championship. We are past 1/3 of the calendar and Wolff already started speaking about 2023
Ferrari upgrade looked good yesterday.
Based on newer betting odds https://www.covers.com/f1/drivers-championship-constructors-championship-odds
Friend who's F1 fan passed on assertion that "Teams will never let the No. 2's win the championship, barring injury to no. 1"
Mainly based on current standings assuming we're ~1/4 of the way through the season based on scores from previous years.
Initial placeholder guesstimates only.
Mercedes are not showing any improvements.

Ferrari at their strongest for some years, but MV is reigning world champion and still in a very good car. Red Bull have recent experience of competing successfully for the Driver Championship and seem less prone to tactical in-race errors than Ferrari. Perez less error-prone than Sainz so far this season. Mercedes still too far off the pace to compete for wins and would need their rivals to underperform consistently to have any chance of closing the points gap in the early standings.

Sainz and Perez are very unlikely to beat their teammates, especially given the points deficit as of today. Add this to the uncertainty of the car development, I give them both a very low chance of winning the WDC.

Starting with odds data from betting markets (like this one: https://www.sportsbettingdime.com/racing/formula-1-drivers-championship-odds/), I was able to convert to percentages as some other posters have done:

RBR have a solid track record of in-season car development, and operates with a clear first-driver strategy. The major flaws of engine reliability should be behind them, and Max's consistency as a driver is above his major competitors.

Updating post-Spain. With his current momentum, this season seems to be Verstappen’s to lose. Much racing left and much scope for new development, so far too early to get too excited (or worried, depending).

It's basically 50/50 between LeClerc and Verstappen. Ferrari and Red Bull are very close in terms of performance (any circuit may favour one or the other, but the effect cancels out over the 17 races left).

So far in the season Verstappen and Leclerc have won every race, Leclerc has a 19 point edge on Verstappen, who has a 19 point edge on Perez. It already is shaping up to be a two driver battle for the title, though Perez and Sainz have an outside shot (driving the same cars as Verstappen and Leclerc respectively). Maybe Mercades could come back, but it seems unlikely unless the car improves drastically.

Mercedes in the mud for a while I think. For how great Ferrari start been, Verstappen has more wins currently. Don't think it will be a procession, but big questions if Ferrari this season can progress the car and not stagnate.
As literally posed, “100% Verstappen” is the right answer to the question…presumably they will soon fix it to ask for the 2022 champ!
I don’t expect both Red Bull drivers in the top 3. I think Max Verstappen and George Russell are technically better drivers, although Charles Leclerc is leading at this moment.
Going based initially on the people that have the most to lose: https://www.vegasinsider.com/auto-racing/odds/f1/
